prompt.p: A 29-year-old woman complains of a gradual increase in a painless neck swelling. The history reveals that she has remained well and she has sought advice for cosmetic reasons. Inspection of her neck is shown in the figure.
What features of this swelling would you expect to elicit on clinical examination?
Douglas et al, Macleod's Clinical Examination , 11 th edn.

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Depression of the swelling on swallowing
Elevation of the swelling on tongue protrusion
The swelling is pulsatile on palpation

modalFeedback.p: Option B is Correct. This occurs with a thyroglossal cyst due to its embryological connection to the foramen caecum of the tongue.
[Fig. reproduced from Douglas et al, Macleod's Clinical Examination , 11 th edn., 2005, with permission from Elsevier. Fig. 9.19 Thyroglossal cyst]
Option A is Incorrect. Elevation would occur with swallowing.
Option C is Incorrect. A brachial cyst may have a sinus and may be tender if infected. It will not be in the midline.
Option D is Incorrect. This occurs with a pharyngeal pouch. It is more prevalent in men and the elderly. The patient's history does not fit this diagnosis.
Option E is Incorrect. A carotid swelling will be pulsatile (a glomus tumour or aneurysm).
